isis.stitle: DT/DTA-466 Diesel Engine Service (1990) - LUBRICATING OIL PUMP, OIL FILTERS AND COOLER - LUBRICATING OIL PUMP - INCREASED CAPACITY LUBE OIL SYSTEM

svcprocinfo.para: Effective with engine Serial No. 466776 and above, all DT 466 and all serial No. DTA 466 diesel engines are equipped with an "increased capacity" lube oil system to accommodate future high horse power ratings and lower rated engine speeds. The following components have been revised to achieve the improved lube oil system.

svcsubproc.title: Oil Pump
svcsubproc.para: The increased capacity lube oil system uses a larger Gerotor oil pump, than the pump used on earlier engines. Changes to the oil pump components include:

step1.para:
A "increased capacity" oil pump housing with a 31.56±0.025 mm (1.2425 ± 0.001 in.) wide rotor bore, versus the displaced "standard" oil pump housing with a 26.25±0.025 mm (1.0335 ±.001 in.) wide rotor bore ( Figure 9.5
).

figure.caption: Figure 9.5. Lube Oil Pump Housing Comparison.

step1.para:
The "increased capacity" inner and outer rotors have a revised width of 31.47±0.010 mm (1.2391 ± 0.0004 in.) as compared to the "standard" rotors with a width of 26.16±0.010 mm (1.0301± 0.0004 in.). Refer to Figure 9.6
.

note.para: WIDE AND NARROW ROTORS AS WELL AS LUBE OIL PUMP HOUSINGS ARE NOT INTERCHANGEABLE AND ARE NOT SERVICED INDIVIDUALLY. DO NOT ATTEMPT TO INTERMIX COMPONENTS.

figure.caption: Figure 9.6. Increased Capacity vs. Standard Capacity Rotor Comparison.

step1.para:
The oil pump housing plate has an increased radius of 41.14 vs. 39.62 mm (1.62 vs.1.56 in.) at the mating surface of crankcase front cover. The larger radius accommodates changes made to the front cover used with the "increased capacity" lube oil system ( Figure 9.7
).

note.para: OIL PUMP HOUSING PLATE IS SERVICED INDIVIDUALLY. THE REVISED OIL PUMP HOUSING PLATE WITH THE 41.14 mm (1.62 in.) RADIUS MAY BE USED WITH BOTH "INCREASED CAPACITY" AND "STANDARD CAPACITY" OIL PUMPS. HOWEVER, DISPLACED PLATE WITH THE 39.62 mm (1.56 in.) RADIUS MAY ONLY BE USED WITH "STANDARD CAPACITY" OIL PUMPS.

svcsubproc.title: Oil Pump Inlet Tube Assembly
svcsubproc.para: The "increased capacity" lube oil system uses an oil pump inlet tube assembly which is larger than the "standard capacity" tube assembly. The larger oil inlet tube assembly accommodates the increased volume of oil pumped by the revised oil pump.
Changes to oil pump inlet tube assembly include:

step1.para:
An "increased capacity" oil pump inlet tube and screen assembly, with a 38.22±0.050 mm (1.505±0.002 in.) diameter neck and 41.14 mm (1.62 in) diameter screen opening which is used in place of the "standard capacity" oil pump inlet tube assembly with a 32.0±0.127 mm (1.260±.005 in.) diameter neck and 33.52 mm (1.32 in.) diameter screen opening. Refer to Figures 9.8
and
9.9
.

figure.caption: Figure 9.8. Increased vs. Standard Capacity Oil Pump Inlet Tube Assembly (Used With the Front Sump Oil Pan).

step1.para:
An enlarged oil pump inlet tube with a 38.1±0.050 mm (1.500±.002 in.) O.D. is used in place of the "standard capacity" tube with a 31.75±0.127 mm (1.250±.005 in.) O.D. Refer to Figures 9.8
and
9.9
.

The oil inlet tube elbow, which is enlarged to accommodate the other revised components of the oil pump inlet tube assembly. Refer to Figures 9.8
and
9.9
.

The oil pump inlet support, which is revised to assure secure oil pump inlet tube assembly mounting. Refer to Figures 9.8
and
9.9
.

warning.para: DO NOT USE THE "STANDARD" INLET TUBE WITH THE NEW FRONT COVER. INTERMIXING THE "STANDARD" INLET TUBE WITH THE NEW FRONT COVER WILL RESULT IN SEVERE ENGINE DAMAGE DUE TO LOW OIL PRESSURE.

figure.caption: Figure 9.9. Increased vs. Standard Capacity Oil Pump Inlet Tube Assembly (Used With the Rear Sump Oil Pan).

svcsubproc.title: Oil Pressure Regulating Valve
svcsubproc.para:
The Oil Pressure Regulating Valve Assembly, has a revised regulating valve and regulating valve housing. See Figure 9.10
. to accommodate the increased capacity of the oil pump.

figure.caption: Figure 9.10. Oil Pressure Regulating Valve Old vs. New (Installed Cross-sectional View).

svcsubproc.title: Crankcase Front Cover
svcsubproc.para:
The crankcase front cover has been revised to include an enlarged oil inlet opening and passage which is required for use with the "increased capacity" oil pump and oil pump inlet tube assemblies. Refer to Figure 9.11
. The larger front cover oil inlet passage assures unrestricted oil flow to the "increased capacity" lube oil pump.

When disassembled, the "increased capacity" and "standard capacity" front covers can be visually identified by examining the oil pump inlet tube mounting pad and passage located on the rear of the front cover ( Figure 9.11
). When assembled, the front cover is best identified by the production part number cast on the front surface of the front cover. The table below may be used to identify the "increased capacity" and "standard capacity" front covers.

entry.para: "Increased Capacity" Front Cover Production Part Numbers*
"Standard Capacity" Front Cover Production Part Numbers*

para.emph: * Production only part numbers are for identification purposes only. Do Not attempt to order service parts using these numbers. Refer to "Engine Parts Catalog" for service part numbers.

svcsubproc.title: Revised Gaskets and Gasket Package
svcsubproc.para:
A new oil inlet tube gasket is released for service to accommodate the revised oil pump inlet tube assembly and front cover used with the "increased capacity" lube oil system. Refer to Figure 9.12
.

The front cover gasket package is revised to include the "increased capacity" oil inlet tube gasket. This revised front cover gasket package is now part of the crankcase gasket service package. Refer to the "Engine Parts Catalog" for a listing of part numbers and package contents.

step1.para: Remove the vibration damper as described in VIBRATION DAMPER, CRANKSHAFT, MAIN BEARINGS, FLYWHEEL AND CRANKCASE.

Using a hammer and chisel, remove the woodruff key from the crankshaft as shown in Figure 9.13
.

Remove the six oil pump housing retaining bolts and washers as shown in Figure 9.14
.

note.para: Whenever the oil pump housing is removed from the crankcase front cover, be careful not to mix the six oil pump housing bolts with any other hardware. These bolts have a nylon patch mounted in the threads to seal through-tapped holes which go into the oil cavity behind the crankcase front cover. Installation of cap screws not so equipped will result in oil leaks around these cap screws. The leaks will not be obvious until after the engine has been put back into service. To prevent the possible loss of the bolts' sealing characteristic, the prevailing torque bolts should not be reused more than three times.

step1.para:
Remove the oil pump housing with O-Ring seal from the front cover. Refer to Figure 9.15
. Discard the O-Ring seal.

figure.caption: Figure 9.13. Remove Woodruff Key from Crankshaft.
Figure 9.14. Remove Oil Pump Housing Bolts.

step1.para:
Remove the inner and outer rotors from the oil pump drive spline. Refer to Figure 9.15
.

Remove the oil pump housing plate. With the plate removed, remove the oil pump housing ring from the front cover. Refer to Figure 9.16
. Discard the ring.
Remove the oil seal from the oil pump housing. Discard the seal.
